hints.content: In this fact family, the $\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black}$ is $\color{purple}10\color{black}$.The $\color{green}\color{black}\text{number of the groups}\color{black}$ is $\color{green}\color{black}5$.The $\color{maroon}\text{size of each group}\color{black}$ is $\color{maroon}2$.[[image 0]]

We can relate the tape diagram to multiplication:
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} \times \color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} = \color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} $
$\color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} \times \color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} = \color{purple}\text{total}\color{black}$
So, $\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}\times\color{maroon}2\color{black} = \color{purple}10\color{black}$ is one way to represent this image.

We can also relate the tape diagram to division.
$\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} \div \color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} =\color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} $
$\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} \div \color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} =\color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$
So, $\color{purple}10\color{black} \div \color{maroon}2\color{black} =\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}$ is another way to represent this image.

Multiplication: $\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}\times\color{maroon}2\color{black}=\color{purple}10\color{black}$Division: $\color{purple}10\color{black} \div \color{maroon}2\color{black} =\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}$

question.content: **Which equations can the tape diagram represent?**[[image 0]]

hints.content:
We can think of division as the following: 
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}=\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}$

We know the $\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}$:There are $\color{green}\color{black}30\color{black}$ books total.And we know the $\color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$:There are $\color{blue}D6$ boxes.

To find out how many books are in each box, we can divide the $\color{green}\color{black}30\color{black}$ books into $\color{blue}D6$ groups.$\color{green}\color{black}30\color{black}\div\color{blue}D6$

question.content: Tom has $30$ books divided evenly into $6$ boxes.**Which expression helps us find out how many books are in each box?**

hints.content:
We can think of division as the following: 
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}=\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}$

We know the $\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}$:There are $\color{green}\color{black}48\color{black}$ people.And we know the $\color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$:There are $\color{blue}D8$ tables.

Let's put those numbers in the equation.
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\color{black}48\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}8\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$

The quotient will tell us the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$.In this problem, the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$ is the $\color{purple}\text{number people at each table}\color{black}$.
The quotient tells us the $\color{purple}\text{number of people at each table}\color{black}$.

options: Number of people at each table
correctAnswers: Number of people at each table

hints.content: There are $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}$ ladybugs.We can look at $\color{green}\color{black}\text{how many equal-sized groups of ladybugs}\color{black}$  there are or $\color{maroon}\text{how many ladybugs are in every group}\color{black}$.

### $\color{green}\color{black}\text{Number of equal-sized groups}\color{black}$There are $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}$ total ladybugs divided into $\color{green}\color{black}7$ equal groups.[[image 0]][[image 1]][[image 2]][[image 3]][[image 4]][[image 5]][[image 6]]
$\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}$ divided into $\color{green}\color{black}7$ equal groups is $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}\div\color{green}\color{black}7$.

### $\color{maroon}\text{Number of ladybugs in each group}\color{black}$There are $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}$ ladybugs total divided into groups of $\color{maroon}4$ ladybugs.[[image 0]][[image 1]][[image 2]][[image 3]][[image 4]][[image 5]][[image 6]]
$\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}$ divided into groups of $\color{maroon}4$ is $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}\div \color{maroon}4$.

The following expressions could represent the picture:-  $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}\div \color{green}\color{black}7$ 
- $\color{blue}\color{black}28\color{black}\div \color{maroon}4$

We can relate the tape diagram to multiplication:
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} \times \color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} = \color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} $
$\color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} \times \color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} = \color{purple}\text{total}\color{black}$
So, $\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}\times\color{maroon}2\color{black} = \color{purple}10\color{black}$ is one way to represent this image.

We can also relate the tape diagram to division.
$\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} \div \color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} =\color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} $
$\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} \div \color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} =\color{green}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$
So, $\color{purple}10\color{black} \div \color{maroon}2\color{black} =\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}$ is another way to represent this image.

Multiplication: $\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}\times\color{maroon}2\color{black}=\color{purple}10\color{black}$Division: $\color{purple}10\color{black} \div \color{maroon}2\color{black} =\color{green}\color{black}5\color{black}$

hints.content:
Multiplication and division are related:
$\color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} \times \color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} = \color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} $
$\color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} \times \color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} = \color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} $

$\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} \div \color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black} =\color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} $
$\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black} \div \color{maroon}\text{size of groups}\color{black} =\color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$

In this fact family, the $\color{purple}\text{total}\color{black}$ is $\color{purple}20\color{black}$.The $\color{maroon}\text{size of each group}\color{black}$ is $\color{maroon}5$.The $\color{blue}\color{black}\text{number of the groups}\color{black}$ is $\color{blue}E4$.[[image 0]]

So,
$\color{blue}\color{black}4\color{black}\times\color{maroon}5\color{black} = \color{purple}20\color{black}$
$\color{purple}20\color{black} \div \color{maroon}5\color{black} = \color{blue}\color{black}4\color{black}$

These number sentences show the same relationship:-  $4 \times 5 = 20$
- $20\div 5 = 4$

We can relate division to arrays:
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of rows}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ number of objects in each row}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ number of objects in each row}\color{black}=\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of rows}\color{black}$
There are $\color{blue}D2$ rows with $\color{purple}9$ dots in each row.[[image 0]]There are $\color{green}\color{black}18\color{black}$ total dots.

$\color{green}\color{black}18\color{black}\text{ total dots}\div ~\color{purple}9\text{ dots in each row}= \color{blue}D2\text{ rows}$
$\color{green}\color{black}18\color{black}\text{ total dots}\div \color{blue}D2\text{ rows}  ~=\color{purple}9\text{ dots in each row}$

The following expressions represent the array:- $\color{green}\color{black}18\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$
- $\color{green}\color{black}18\color{black}\div\color{blue}D2$

hints.content: Each pack has $\color{purple}8$ cards.Anastasia bought $\color{green}\color{black}64\color{black}$ total cards.[[image 0]]How many $\color{blue}\color{black}\text{groups}\color{black}$ are there?

We can write this as a multiplication problem. $\color{purple}\text{size of the group}\color{black}\times\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of groups}\color{black} = \color{green}\color{black}\text{ total}\color{black}$So, $\color{purple}8\times\color{blue}\color{black}\text{?}\color{black} = \color{green}\color{black}64}$

We can also write this as a division problem. $\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ size of the groups}\color{black}=\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of groups}\color{black} $So, $\color{green}\color{black}64\color{black}\div \color{purple}8=\color{blue}\color{black}\text{?}\color{black}$

The equations that would help us find out how many packs of cards Anastasia bought are: - $\color{purple}8\times\color{blue}\color{black}\text{?}\color{black} = \color{green}\color{black}64\color{black}$  
 - $\color{green}\color{black}64\color{black}\div \color{purple}8=\color{blue}\color{black}\text{?}\color{black}$

question.content: Anastasia buys several packs of  Wonky Wizard trading cards.  Each pack has $8$ cards, and Anastasia buys a total of $64$ cards.  **Which equations would help us find out how many packs of cards Anastasia bought?**

hints.content: There are $\color{green}\color{black}20\color{black}$ boxes in $\color{blue}D4$ equal rows.[Same image with the rows numbered 1 through 4 and horizontal lines between the rows][[https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/51eafe193502a2b098331835dd9afbe0744f26de.svg]]How can we find out how many boxes are in each row?

We can find how many boxes are in each row by dividing:$\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of rows}\color{black}$So, $\color{green}\color{black}20\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}4\color{black}$
The following expression will tell us how many boxes are in each row:- $\color{green}\color{black}20\color{black}\div\color{blue}D4$

hints.content: There are $\color{blue}\color{black}3\color{black}$ periods.The Rangers score $\color{green}\color{black}6\color{black}$ total goals.[[image 0]]What is the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$?

We can write this as a multiplication problem. $\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of groups}\color{black}\times\color{purple}\text{size of the group}\color{black}= \color{green}\color{black}\text{ total}\color{black}$So, $\color{blue}\color{black}3\color{black}\times\color{purple}\text{?}\color{black} = \color{green}\color{black}6\color{black}$

We can also write this as a division problem. $\color{green}\color{black}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\color{black}\text{ number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ size of the groups}\color{black}$So, $\color{green}\color{black}6\color{black}\div \color{blue}\color{black}3\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{?}\color{black}$

The equations that would help us find out how many goals the Rangers scored in each period are:   - $\color{blue}\color{black}3\color{black}\times\color{purple}\text{?}\color{black} = \color{green}\color{black}6\color{black}$
 - $\color{green}\color{black}6\color{black}\div \color{blue}\color{black}3\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{?}\color{black}$

hints.content: The expression $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}D3$ can represent $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}$ total items split evenly into $\color{blue}D3$ groups.Which problem wants to split $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}$ into $\color{blue}D3$ equal groups?

###GinoWe want to find out how many walnut trees are left, so we subtract $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black} - \color{maroon}3$.$\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}D3$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###LindseyWe want to find out how many apples there are, so we multiply $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black} \times \color{maroon}3$.$\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}D3$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###LaTashaWe want to split the $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}$ stickers evenly onto $\color{blue}D3$ pieces of paper.  So, we divide $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}D3$.$\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}D3$ helps us solve this problem

The expression $\color{green}\color{black}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}D3$ can solve the following context:- LaTasha has $27$ rabbit stickers. She splits the stickers evenly among $3$ pieces of paper. How many stickers did LaTasha put on each piece of paper?

question.content: **Which problem can we solve with $27\div3$?**

options: LaTasha has $27$ rabbit stickers. She splits the stickers evenly among $3$ pieces of paper. How many stickers did LaTasha put on each piece of paper?
Gino had $27$ walnut trees in his yard. He cut $3$ down to use for firewood. How many walnut trees does Gino have left?
Lindsey picked $3$ bags of apples. There are $27$ apples in each bag. How many apples does she have in total?
correctAnswers: LaTasha has $27$ rabbit stickers. She splits the stickers evenly among $3$ pieces of paper. How many stickers did LaTasha put on each piece of paper?
